Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI:Depth Limitations of Biofilm Extraction From Groundwater Wells Using Sonication
Award.AbstractNarration:
Groundwater microbial communities are traditionally analyzed through extracting water samples from monitoring wells. It is well known that most of the microbial biomass in groundwater exists as surface-attached organisms (biofilm); however, this fraction is often underrepresented in groundwater analysis. Biofilm assessment can be improved through creating conditions to physically detach microorganisms from sediment surface. Sonication with low-frequency acoustic waves, for example, creates a pressure change in the sediment that loosens and detaches the biofilm. The efficacy of this treatment decreases with increased distance from the sonicator. Currently, pre-treatment efficacy at depths greater than 1 m below the water table is unknown. Through collaboration with Murray Close of the Institute of Environmental Science and Research (ESR), this research will examine the extraction quality of in-situ sonication at varying depths. This may shed light on the limits of in-situ sonication and improve microbial assessment in groundwater. Accurate assessment is important because microorganisms play key roles in nutrient cycles and contaminant degradation.

Using established sites in Canterbury, New Zealand, groundwater samples will be retrieved from two monitoring wells before and after application of a low frequency sonicator. The sonicator will be used at increasing depths (e.g. 1 m, 4 m, and 7 m) below the water table for each trial and three sonication pulses at 1.6 kW at 50 minute intervals will be induced each time. The biomass of aquifer microorganisms will be determined for each sample using assays available at ESR. Biofilm extraction quality will be assessed by comparing this biomass against (1) the microbial biomass collected from established sediment cores in the wells (biofilm) and (2) the microbial biomass collected from the well before sonication (suspended microorganisms). This research is funded in collaboration with the Royal Society of New Zealand.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Kimberly Huynh has completed her research “Influence of depth on enhancing biofilm extraction from aquifers through in-situ sonication” supported by the NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes for U.S. Graduate Students (EAPSI). During her funding period, she spent two months at the Institute of Environmental Science and Research (Christchurch, New Zealand). Her collaborator was Murray Close, a staff scientist in the groundwater research group. Her work focused on improving microbial assessments of groundwater quality. Groundwater is typically assessed via extractions from groundwater wells. This leads to an underrepresentation of biofilm, or attached microorganisms, in water sampling. Accurately assessing microbial life in aquifers is important because microorganisms are responsible for the majority of primary production in groundwater.

Three fieldwork campaigns were accomplished over two months. Groundwater samples were collected at varying depths and at varying times post-sonication. These samples were compared against biofilm grown in-situ in the groundwater wells months prior to the campaigns. Heterotrophic plate counts (HPC) and turbidity were measured to assess microbial quantities. Sonication improved the extraction efficiency up to 84-fold compared to background values and were similar to the levels extracted from the in-situ biofilm samples. In-situ sonication across all depths greatly increased extraction efficiency, making this technique a cost-effective tool for improved groundwater microbial assessment.

 

This research was presented as a poster at the American Geophysical Fall Union Fall Meeting 2015. This is the largest conference in Earth and space science, drawing over 24,000 attendees each year. As outreach, Kimberly has described her research one-on-one with her mentees in the Graduate Student Pathways Symposium program at the University of California, Berkeley. She will present her research to a group of undergraduate students interested in graduate school who have been historically underrepresented in STEM.


This research had been an expansion of her undergraduate honors thesis conducted under Professor Aaron Packman at Northwestern University.
